Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W58-13T1-JBHT-D3G8-00000-00Kasie DC Panel with Rep. Ro Khanna (D-CA)2019-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:06ZLexisNexisKasie DC Panel with Rep. Ro Khanna (D-CA)LanhamFULL TEXT

KASIE HUNT, MSNBC HOST: Welcome to the second hour of KASIE DC.

Joining me here on set: a member of the House Oversight Committee and co-chair of Senator Bernie Sanders`s presidential campaign, Democratic Congressman Ro Khanna of California, "Washington Post" White House bureau chief and MSNBC political analyst Philip Rucker, campaign director for the Center for American Progress Action Fund, Juanita Tolliver, and author of "The Washington Post`s" "Power Up" newsletter, Jackie Alemany.

In real-time and full public view, Congress and the White House are testing the limits of their power. Phil and Jackie`s colleagues at "The Washington Post" report that President Trump and his allies are working to block more than 20 separate investigations by Democrats into his actions as president, his personal finances, and his administration`s policies.

House Democrats say the Trump administration has failed to respond to or comply with at least 79 requests for documents or other information. The president is blocking aides from testifying, refusing entire document requests from some committees, filing lawsuits against corporations to bar them from responding to subpoenas, and asserting executive privilege to keep information about the special counsel`s Russia investigation out of public view. And one of the points that the piece makes is that some congressional experts fear the strategy could undermine the institutional power of Congress for years to come.

But, Congressman Khanna, what is the strategy here for Democrats as you simply watch the president refuse request after request after request and subpoena after subpoena?

REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA): Well, Kasie, it`s an assault on the idea of separation of powers. Look, every administration pushes back against Congress. That`s normal and you have these fights. But no administration denies every single request. That`s what`s going on here. They are simply refusing to recognize Congress` role of oversight.

There is only one thing we can do, and that`s the courts.

HUNT: Is there a risk there? I mean, what is the kind of thinking behind the scenes as to how to approach that without getting a court decision that stops you in your tracks?

KHANNA: Well, I think the courts will rule clearly for us, because the law is clear. Unless there is national security at stake, when there are issues of obstruction or corrupt action in the executive branch, the Congress has clear ability to get these documents. And I think courts are ruling expeditiously. We just had the D.C. court -- a court in D.C. say that they aren`t going to stonewall. So, I expect that the courts will rule for us, and they`ll rule expeditiously.

HUNT: Juanita, you kind of worked in the Center for American Progress which is very in touch, of course, with the base of the Democratic Party. What`s your view of how Democrats in Congress are kind of going about this and whether they should be more aggressive than perhaps they`re being?

JUANITA TOLLIVER, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS FUND CAMPAIGN DIRECTOR: I mean, Democrats in Congress are operating off the mandate in which they retook the house from voters overwhelmingly supporting Democrats in the midterms in 2018. And so, they`re actually really doing a great job of conducting that oversight. Of course, there is tension on how far to go, but I think recent polling showed that a lot of Democratic voters really want to wait for additional evidence. They want the oversight to run its course.

And so I think it`s really falling in line with what we`ve seen from Speaker Pelosi and Democratic leadership on Congress that hey, steady the course. Let`s tow that line because let`s not -- we`re not going to fall into the trap that Trump wants us to by pulling the ultimate card of impeachment.

HUNT: Jackie, I mean, Pelosi said this week that the president is trying to goad Democrats into impeachment. But at the same time, they seem to be moving the line a little bit, closer and closer.

JACKIE ALEMANY, AUTHOR, "POWER UP" NEWSLETTER, THE WASHINGTON POST: That`s exactly right. Over the past few weeks, where you have really seen Pelosi`s position evolve here. She was pretty conservative at first, and now, she`s using terms like self-impeachment and goading.

But if you notice that language really puts the burden back on the president because I think she still is hesitant here. There is immense frustration amongst Democrats. I`m sure you can speak better to that than I can, but, you know, there is clearly an issue enforcement mechanisms working here.

And, you know, at the end of the day, this is a fight that the president wants to be having. He`d much rather be talk about fighting these oversight battles than talking about, you know, the crises going on in Venezuela, China, North Korea, Iran, and Russia.

HUNT: Is that -- I mean, is that sort of the thinking behind the scenes here, Phil, that this is good ground for the president to be on to solidify his base?

PHIL RUCKER, MSNBC POLITICAL ANALYST: Absolutely, because he can make himself the victim and the persecuted, and he can argue that the Democrats are reaching beyond what is reasonable in the Congress to investigate him, and to try to force him out of office somehow.

HUNT: We are losing our light here is in our studio. Sorry, Phil. We didn`t mean to interrupt you. I think we`re still on the air. But to all of our viewers who are now watching us in the dark, I sincerely apologize.

All right. I think we`re back. So, we`ll keep going. I know.

(CROSSTALK)

HUNT: Better look out. Maybe there is dragons outside the studio somewhere.

Phil, I`m so sorry you were interrupted. Please continue.

RUCKER: One thing we should really keep in mind, though, is the scope and breadth of these investigations. There are 20 investigations. It`s not just about Russia and obstruction of justice and interference in the election, but it`s looking into the security clearance process at the White House. You know, how is it that Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump got their security clearances despite the objections of career staff?

It`s looking into the president`s personal finances, his tax returns. Who does he owe money to? Where is that money coming from? These are accountability measures that were missing in the first two years of the administration because the Republicans controlled both houses of Congress. And the Democrats are trying to catch up.

HUNT: Congressman, I mean, what -- how far would you say this line is moving? I mean, is your caucus in general when you guys get together behind the scenes -- I mean, Nancy Pelosi has her finger on the pulse of that.

KHANNA: She does.

HUNT: You know, unlike anyone. And to hear her moving in this direction tells me there is something building inside your caucus. How strong is it at this point?

KHANNA: Well, there is greater and greater frustration. I mean, there was first frustration when the ten counts of obstruction were detailed. Then there is frustration when the president refuses to comply with anything and is basically insulting members of Congress and our constitutional duty.

But Nancy Pelosi is very clear. The speaker believes we need to have public sentiment with us, and we are to make that case. And she will move when public sentiment moves. She quotes Abraham Lincoln all the time. Public sentiment is everything.

So, she is -- anyone who knows her knows how she is looking at this. She wants to build a case and then she is going to see where public sentiment is.

HUNT: I mean, Jackie, what`s your sense of -- I mean, having -- I know you look at the polling when you put together your newsletter and all that. I mean, public sentiment has not moved towards -- in favor of impeachment.

ALEMANY: No, it hasn`t. And you even have people like Senator Sanders who are saying to voters on the campaign trail, even though he`s -- you know, he`s trying to fund-raise off the Mueller report, he`s saying to voters, when we`re talking about Mueller, when we`re talking about all of these oversight pushes, we`re not talking about health care and issues that affect the American people on a consistent basis.

And so, I think Speaker Pelosi does realize that the more time everyone is spending, the more air time everyone is spending on talking about these fights feeds into what the president is talking about, it helps distract from issues of health care -- trade, tax issues, of potentially repealing the president`s tax bill.

HUNT: We get that bombshell "New York Times" report on the president`s finances. The push for more details is also going on.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): In his mind, he is wildly successful. That`s part of his branding, is to be bigger than life. By any reasonable definition, he is successful. He is the president of the United States. He owns a bunch of golf courses that are a lot of fun to play. So, the American people figure out about what they want to believe or not believe about Donald Trump and his marketing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: On Tuesday, a federal judge is expected to rule on whether the president can put a stop to a House subpoena demanding financial records from his personal accounting firm. And the ways and means committee issued subpoenas Friday to Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig by this coming Friday.

Over the weekend, the president reflected on the political optics of it all, tweeting, quote: I won the 2016 election partially based on no tax returns while I`m under audit, which I still am, and the voters don`t care making it a part of the 2020 election.

And here is what the IRS commissioner said one month ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SANFORD BISHOP (D-GA): But there is no rule that would prohibit the release of a tax return because it`s under audit.

CHARLES RETTIG, IRS COMMISSIONER: I`m not aware of such a rule. And I believe I`ve answered that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: And let`s just be clear in terms of fact checking the president, Juanita, that, first of all, presidents are audited regularly. And yet we still see tax returns from past residents and, of course, the IRS commissioner did some fact checking for us there saying there is nothing preventing this. But at the same time, it doesn`t necessarily seem as those Democrats have a clear path forward to actually getting these released.

TOLLIVER: Well, I think the clear path forward is what they`re doing already, issue the subpoena, make the request, because what they`ve done now is looped in the IRS commissioner who is not beholden to Trump the way Mnuchin is. And so, it`s really calling on people further down the chain of command. Hey, are you really going to put yourself on the line, put your future on the line to protect a president who is hiding something at this point, and folks have reason to believe?

And I think also in terms of public opinion on this, in polls over the last four to six weeks, there is shown that the majority of Americans do believe that Trump should release his tax returns. I think Democrats have that going in their favor too.

HUNT: Phil, what of these is the most dangerous for the president? I mean, is Democrats going after his tax returns, the biggest, you know, non-Russia problem that he has coming from the Hill or not?

RUCKER: You know, it might be the most embarrassing problem for him so far as if the returns from the more recent years show that the 10-year span that "The New York Times" reported on, it would show that the president is not as rich as he says he is, and that he had a lot of losses and is not the grand golden success that he has pitched himself to the American people as. But I don`t know that that`s politically that dangerous for him, or legally that`s dangerous for him.

If I were President Trump, I would be much more concerned about people like Don McGahn coming in to an open forum and testifying on any number of issues where the president could be implicated, and not only bad behavior, but obstruction of justice or other criminal behavior.

HUNT: Yes, the kicker of that "New York Times" report about his tax returns, about how he said it was difficult to make money in real estate. But his father never lost any money except when he invested in his son.

Anyway, Phil Rucker, thanks so much for being here. We`re sorry again about the lights.

Everyone else is going to stay with us.

So, you have heard this week calls to break up Facebook, even from one of the company`s founders. Now it is turning into a wedge for 2020 candidates in what has been a pretty tame election cycle just got a little more heated.

Plus, her identity as a covert CIA agent was leaked during the Bush administration to settle a political score against her husband. Now, Valerie Plame is running for Congress. She joins me live ahead on KASIE DC.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HUNT: The battle over big tech`s accountability problem is now spilling into the presidential race and pitting 2020 Democrats against each other. Senator Cory Booker is making clear he doesn`t think breaking up tech giants, which Elizabeth Warren has proposed, is a solution. But it`s how Booker describes his disagreement with Warren`s proposal that turned heads.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-NJ), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I don`t think that a president should be running around pointing at companies at companies and say breaking them up without any kind of process here. It`s not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks. That sounds like a Donald Trump thing to say. I`m going to break up you guys.

No. We need to create systems and processes.

INTERVIEWER: You just compared Elizabeth Warren to Donald Trump?

BOOKER: I most certainly did not. She`s my friend --

INTERVIEWER: That`s what she`s saying. She`s the one that`s saying that.

BOOKER: Well, again, she has -- let her discuss and debate her positions. I`m telling you right now, we do not need a president that is going to use their own personal beliefs and tell you which companies we should break up. We need a president who is going to enforce antitrust laws in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: The call to reduce the power of big tech grew loud their week when Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes called the company, quote, dangerous. Hughes wrote in a "New York Times" op-ed that the government must, quote, break up Facebook`s monopoly.

And this morning, Senator Kamala Harris was also asked to weigh in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: There is no question in my mind that there needs to be serious regulation, and that has not been happening there needs to be more oversight that has not been happening.

INTERVIEWER: You think they should be broken up?

HARRIS: Yes, I think we have to seriously take a look at that, yes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: Quite some comments from Cory Booker.

Congressman, I know you represent Silicon Valley. So, I want to get your take on this in a minute.

But, Jackie, just to kind of look at this from the lens of Cory Booker essentially calling Elizabeth Warren Trumpian in her kind of attack on this on Facebook. At the same time, I mean, it isn`t just any random company that she might have a personal vendetta against.

ALEMANY: No, it`s not. And this has been Elizabeth Warren`s pretty consistent position. It is really interesting as the campaign progresses to finally see positions, different positions between candidates in the Democratic Party differentiating from themselves. Cory Booker sort of, you know, appearing to take actually the sides of corporations a little bit more than Elizabeth Warren, which I think is a standpoint that you could have surmised from their positions in Congress.

But, you know, they both are part of a Congress that has failed really to regulate Facebook over the last few years, and I think both of them really need to grapple with their role in that. You know, France just finished their review in which the government conducted a six-month review internally in Facebook overseeing how their regulatory processes work and actually provided a report which Zuckerberg praised. And so, I don`t think these two things, breaking up Facebook and increasing regulation are necessarily mutually exclusive.

HUNT: Yes, Congressman, to that point about Congress -- I mean, do you think that the United States Congress is equipped to regulate these big tech companies, specifically Facebook? Are they capable of it?

KHANNA: We need to have more technology and knowledge. But we need to look to the Microsoft case. I think that was an example that worked, that government went after Microsoft. They said you couldn`t tie Internet Explorer to Windows. If you had done that, the Microsoft --

HUNT: We would all have to use Internet Explorer and our lives would be way harder and --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

KHANNA: Google would never have emerged, right? But it went to the D.C. Circuit, and the D.C. Circuit said you don`t have break them up. You need to make sure they can`t do bad mergers, they can`t be privileging their own platforms. So, there may be kind of ground.

I do think Elizabeth Warren has added a lot to the debate. I mean, she has called for stronger, thoughtful regulation. The question is, how do we get there? And I think the Microsoft case offers the paradigm.

HUNT: I`m going to put you a little bit on the spot here.

KHANNA: Sure.

HUNT: And I will admit that, you know, I`m not intimately familiar with where Bernie Sanders stands on this question. But you are co-chair of his campaign. Where does he fall on the spectrum of these 2020 candidates?

KHANNA: I haven`t asked him specifically. He usually focuses on Wall Street and defense contractors and airline industries. I mean, I don`t know his exact position on this. But I do know when he talks about technology, he often talks about how do we get universal broadband, how do we get technology into rural communities and jobs there. But you`d have to ask him or his campaign --

HUNT: Well, you are his campaign. That`s why I`m asking you.

KHANNA: I`m one of his co-chairs. I don`t want to -- I don`t want to misrepresent his nuanced view on this without talking to him about it.

HUNT: So, when it comes to the idea of breaking up Facebook, I mean, I think a lot of people, sort of, you know, Chris Hughes really turned heads because to explore your Microsoft analogy a little further, I mean, you`re talking about a centralization of power that is much different from a company that is selling computers and softwares to consumers, right? You`re instead talking about the fact that because all these people are using this platform, the platform itself has immense power.

How do you actually -- I mean, you must have to take steps that are slightly different than what happened in the Microsoft case to actually make it work.

KHANNA: Well, I think if you had scrutiny on mergers, right, I thought they shouldn`t have been allowed to acquire Instagram. I thought they shouldn`t have been allowed to acquire WhatsApp. And if you have different social media platforms, then you a choice.

I mean, I don`t think it`s the end of the world if someone doesn`t use Facebook. It would be the end of the world if someone didn`t have access to the Internet. That`s why Facebook is a utility. It`s not like water or electricity.

HUNT: Well, for a lot of small businesses, it does serve a purpose like a utility does.

KHANNA: Well, I think that there have to be regulations so that they shouldn`t be able to privilege their own products, they shouldn`t be able to bully vendors.

HUNT: They certainly bully the news industry in some cases as well.

KHANNA: And I think that should be looked at. But what we have to do is have a fact-based investigation and then have thoughtful regulation on privacy, on making sure that they`re not privileging their platform, on making sure they`re not getting a favorable deal against vendors.

But here is -- you say well, why not just break them up? There are two reasons. One, you don`t want China, Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu to become the social media platforms around the world. I mean, there is some competition there and --

HUNT: Do you think Facebook views itself as fundamentally American? Because sometimes when I talk to my sources who work there, they view themselves more as a global company than an American one. I mean, how important do you think that American identity is to Mark Zuckerberg?

KHANNA: I think they know they are an American company because they would never have succeeded under Chinese or European laws. I mean, it`s the American First Amendment and Section 230 that allowed a lot of these Internet companies to emerge. They aren`t censored. They have a much more competitive environment than Europe allows.

So, I think they understand that their success, they owed it to America, and they want to make sure some of those values continue.

Now, do they need to be more accountable? Absolutely. They need to do a better job to prevent interference from foreign actors. They need to do a better job to protect privacy. They need to do a better job to create jobs and not just in my district, but across the country.

They need to hire more people of color. It`s dismal what the hiring is of African Americans, African-American women.

So there are a lot of issues we can talk about. But we also should look at their success. The #MeToo movement wouldn`t have happened in the extent it did without Facebook. Black Lives Matter used Facebook. Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders, Donald Trump, they all use Facebook.

You know, Josh Hawley, the senator from Missouri, criticizing Titter saying we don`t need it. Well, why don`t you get off the platforms then? Of course the social media platforms have been critical to democracy. We need to make sure that they`re doing it in a positive way.

HUNT: Well, it seems like the question whether they have fundamentally, Juanita, undermined democracy by empowering authoritarians and misinformation.

TOLLIVER: I think that`s exactly right. With 2020 election coming up, all sorts of alarm bells are going off. Will our election be interfered in through this platform of Facebook, something that I think there has been a lot of evidence of? So how are user data being protected? How are consumers being protected, folks like you and me who use these platforms?

I think the other thing here is these candidates, while they`re on a spectrum, still belief in those same fundamental components, protect consumer data, ensure innovation in the industry and make sure that this platform is working for the American good.

HUNT: All right. Congressman Ro Khanna, thank you very much for coming on.

KHANNA: Thank you.

HUNT: It was always great, this particular conversation, it`s very interesting to have with you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WB8-DDH1-DY0W-40YB-00000-00Kasie DC Panel with Rep. Ro Khanna (D-CA)2019-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:06ZLexisNexisKasie DC Panel with Rep. Ro Khanna (D-CA)LanhamFULL TEXT

KASIE HUNT, MSNBC HOST: Welcome to the second hour of KASIE DC.

Joining me here on set: a member of the House Oversight Committee and co-chair of Senator Bernie Sanders`s presidential campaign, Democratic Congressman Ro Khanna of California, "Washington Post" White House bureau chief and MSNBC political analyst Philip Rucker, campaign director for the Center for American Progress Action Fund, Juanita Tolliver, and author of "The Washington Post`s" "Power Up" newsletter, Jackie Alemany.

In real-time and full public view, Congress and the White House are testing the limits of their power. Phil and Jackie`s colleagues at "The Washington Post" report that President Trump and his allies are working to block more than 20 separate investigations by Democrats into his actions as president, his personal finances, and his administration`s policies.

House Democrats say the Trump administration has failed to respond to or comply with at least 79 requests for documents or other information. The president is blocking aides from testifying, refusing entire document requests from some committees, filing lawsuits against corporations to bar them from responding to subpoenas, and asserting executive privilege to keep information about the special counsel`s Russia investigation out of public view. And one of the points that the piece makes is that some congressional experts fear the strategy could undermine the institutional power of Congress for years to come.

But, Congressman Khanna, what is the strategy here for Democrats as you simply watch the president refuse request after request after request and subpoena after subpoena?

REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA): Well, Kasie, it`s an assault on the idea of separation of powers. Look, every administration pushes back against Congress. That`s normal and you have these fights. But no administration denies every single request. That`s what`s going on here. They are simply refusing to recognize Congress` role of oversight.

There is only one thing we can do, and that`s the courts.

HUNT: Is there a risk there? I mean, what is the kind of thinking behind the scenes as to how to approach that without getting a court decision that stops you in your tracks?

KHANNA: Well, I think the courts will rule clearly for us, because the law is clear. Unless there is national security at stake, when there are issues of obstruction or corrupt action in the executive branch, the Congress has clear ability to get these documents. And I think courts are ruling expeditiously. We just had the D.C. court -- a court in D.C. say that they aren`t going to stonewall. So, I expect that the courts will rule for us, and they`ll rule expeditiously.

HUNT: Juanita, you kind of worked in the Center for American Progress which is very in touch, of course, with the base of the Democratic Party. What`s your view of how Democrats in Congress are kind of going about this and whether they should be more aggressive than perhaps they`re being?

JUANITA TOLLIVER, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS FUND CAMPAIGN DIRECTOR: I mean, Democrats in Congress are operating off the mandate in which they retook the house from voters overwhelmingly supporting Democrats in the midterms in 2018. And so, they`re actually really doing a great job of conducting that oversight. Of course, there is tension on how far to go, but I think recent polling showed that a lot of Democratic voters really want to wait for additional evidence. They want the oversight to run its course.

And so I think it`s really falling in line with what we`ve seen from Speaker Pelosi and Democratic leadership on Congress that hey, steady the course. Let`s tow that line because let`s not -- we`re not going to fall into the trap that Trump wants us to by pulling the ultimate card of impeachment.

HUNT: Jackie, I mean, Pelosi said this week that the president is trying to goad Democrats into impeachment. But at the same time, they seem to be moving the line a little bit, closer and closer.

JACKIE ALEMANY, AUTHOR, "POWER UP" NEWSLETTER, THE WASHINGTON POST: That`s exactly right. Over the past few weeks, where you have really seen Pelosi`s position evolve here. She was pretty conservative at first, and now, she`s using terms like self-impeachment and goading.

But if you notice that language really puts the burden back on the president because I think she still is hesitant here. There is immense frustration amongst Democrats. I`m sure you can speak better to that than I can, but, you know, there is clearly an issue enforcement mechanisms working here.

And, you know, at the end of the day, this is a fight that the president wants to be having. He`d much rather be talk about fighting these oversight battles than talking about, you know, the crises going on in Venezuela, China, North Korea, Iran, and Russia.

HUNT: Is that -- I mean, is that sort of the thinking behind the scenes here, Phil, that this is good ground for the president to be on to solidify his base?

PHIL RUCKER, MSNBC POLITICAL ANALYST: Absolutely, because he can make himself the victim and the persecuted, and he can argue that the Democrats are reaching beyond what is reasonable in the Congress to investigate him, and to try to force him out of office somehow.

HUNT: We are losing our light here is in our studio. Sorry, Phil. We didn`t mean to interrupt you. I think we`re still on the air. But to all of our viewers who are now watching us in the dark, I sincerely apologize.

All right. I think we`re back. So, we`ll keep going. I know.

(CROSSTALK)

HUNT: Better look out. Maybe there is dragons outside the studio somewhere.

Phil, I`m so sorry you were interrupted. Please continue.

RUCKER: One thing we should really keep in mind, though, is the scope and breadth of these investigations. There are 20 investigations. It`s not just about Russia and obstruction of justice and interference in the election, but it`s looking into the security clearance process at the White House. You know, how is it that Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump got their security clearances despite the objections of career staff?

It`s looking into the president`s personal finances, his tax returns. Who does he owe money to? Where is that money coming from? These are accountability measures that were missing in the first two years of the administration because the Republicans controlled both houses of Congress. And the Democrats are trying to catch up.

HUNT: Congressman, I mean, what -- how far would you say this line is moving? I mean, is your caucus in general when you guys get together behind the scenes -- I mean, Nancy Pelosi has her finger on the pulse of that.

KHANNA: She does.

HUNT: You know, unlike anyone. And to hear her moving in this direction tells me there is something building inside your caucus. How strong is it at this point?

KHANNA: Well, there is greater and greater frustration. I mean, there was first frustration when the ten counts of obstruction were detailed. Then there is frustration when the president refuses to comply with anything and is basically insulting members of Congress and our constitutional duty.

But Nancy Pelosi is very clear. The speaker believes we need to have public sentiment with us, and we are to make that case. And she will move when public sentiment moves. She quotes Abraham Lincoln all the time. Public sentiment is everything.

So, she is -- anyone who knows her knows how she is looking at this. She wants to build a case and then she is going to see where public sentiment is.

HUNT: I mean, Jackie, what`s your sense of -- I mean, having -- I know you look at the polling when you put together your newsletter and all that. I mean, public sentiment has not moved towards -- in favor of impeachment.

ALEMANY: No, it hasn`t. And you even have people like Senator Sanders who are saying to voters on the campaign trail, even though he`s -- you know, he`s trying to fund-raise off the Mueller report, he`s saying to voters, when we`re talking about Mueller, when we`re talking about all of these oversight pushes, we`re not talking about health care and issues that affect the American people on a consistent basis.

And so, I think Speaker Pelosi does realize that the more time everyone is spending, the more air time everyone is spending on talking about these fights feeds into what the president is talking about, it helps distract from issues of health care -- trade, tax issues, of potentially repealing the president`s tax bill.

HUNT: We get that bombshell "New York Times" report on the president`s finances. The push for more details is also going on.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): In his mind, he is wildly successful. That`s part of his branding, is to be bigger than life. By any reasonable definition, he is successful. He is the president of the United States. He owns a bunch of golf courses that are a lot of fun to play. So, the American people figure out about what they want to believe or not believe about Donald Trump and his marketing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: On Tuesday, a federal judge is expected to rule on whether the president can put a stop to a House subpoena demanding financial records from his personal accounting firm. And the ways and means committee issued subpoenas Friday to Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig by this coming Friday.

Over the weekend, the president reflected on the political optics of it all, tweeting, quote: I won the 2016 election partially based on no tax returns while I`m under audit, which I still am, and the voters don`t care making it a part of the 2020 election.

And here is what the IRS commissioner said one month ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SANFORD BISHOP (D-GA): But there is no rule that would prohibit the release of a tax return because it`s under audit.

CHARLES RETTIG, IRS COMMISSIONER: I`m not aware of such a rule. And I believe I`ve answered that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: And let`s just be clear in terms of fact checking the president, Juanita, that, first of all, presidents are audited regularly. And yet we still see tax returns from past residents and, of course, the IRS commissioner did some fact checking for us there saying there is nothing preventing this. But at the same time, it doesn`t necessarily seem as those Democrats have a clear path forward to actually getting these released.

TOLLIVER: Well, I think the clear path forward is what they`re doing already, issue the subpoena, make the request, because what they`ve done now is looped in the IRS commissioner who is not beholden to Trump the way Mnuchin is. And so, it`s really calling on people further down the chain of command. Hey, are you really going to put yourself on the line, put your future on the line to protect a president who is hiding something at this point, and folks have reason to believe?

And I think also in terms of public opinion on this, in polls over the last four to six weeks, there is shown that the majority of Americans do believe that Trump should release his tax returns. I think Democrats have that going in their favor too.

HUNT: Phil, what of these is the most dangerous for the president? I mean, is Democrats going after his tax returns, the biggest, you know, non-Russia problem that he has coming from the Hill or not?

RUCKER: You know, it might be the most embarrassing problem for him so far as if the returns from the more recent years show that the 10-year span that "The New York Times" reported on, it would show that the president is not as rich as he says he is, and that he had a lot of losses and is not the grand golden success that he has pitched himself to the American people as. But I don`t know that that`s politically that dangerous for him, or legally that`s dangerous for him.

If I were President Trump, I would be much more concerned about people like Don McGahn coming in to an open forum and testifying on any number of issues where the president could be implicated, and not only bad behavior, but obstruction of justice or other criminal behavior.

HUNT: Yes, the kicker of that "New York Times" report about his tax returns, about how he said it was difficult to make money in real estate. But his father never lost any money except when he invested in his son.

Anyway, Phil Rucker, thanks so much for being here. We`re sorry again about the lights.

Everyone else is going to stay with us.

So, you have heard this week calls to break up Facebook, even from one of the company`s founders. Now it is turning into a wedge for 2020 candidates in what has been a pretty tame election cycle just got a little more heated.

Plus, her identity as a covert CIA agent was leaked during the Bush administration to settle a political score against her husband. Now, Valerie Plame is running for Congress. She joins me live ahead on KASIE DC.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HUNT: The battle over big tech`s accountability problem is now spilling into the presidential race and pitting 2020 Democrats against each other. Senator Cory Booker is making clear he doesn`t think breaking up tech giants, which Elizabeth Warren has proposed, is a solution. But it`s how Booker describes his disagreement with Warren`s proposal that turned heads.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-NJ), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I don`t think that a president should be running around pointing at companies at companies and say breaking them up without any kind of process here. It`s not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks. That sounds like a Donald Trump thing to say. I`m going to break up you guys.

No. We need to create systems and processes.

INTERVIEWER: You just compared Elizabeth Warren to Donald Trump?

BOOKER: I most certainly did not. She`s my friend --

INTERVIEWER: That`s what she`s saying. She`s the one that`s saying that.

BOOKER: Well, again, she has -- let her discuss and debate her positions. I`m telling you right now, we do not need a president that is going to use their own personal beliefs and tell you which companies we should break up. We need a president who is going to enforce antitrust laws in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: The call to reduce the power of big tech grew loud their week when Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes called the company, quote, dangerous. Hughes wrote in a "New York Times" op-ed that the government must, quote, break up Facebook`s monopoly.

And this morning, Senator Kamala Harris was also asked to weigh in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: There is no question in my mind that there needs to be serious regulation, and that has not been happening there needs to be more oversight that has not been happening.

INTERVIEWER: You think they should be broken up?

HARRIS: Yes, I think we have to seriously take a look at that, yes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: Quite some comments from Cory Booker.

Congressman, I know you represent Silicon Valley. So, I want to get your take on this in a minute.

But, Jackie, just to kind of look at this from the lens of Cory Booker essentially calling Elizabeth Warren Trumpian in her kind of attack on this on Facebook. At the same time, I mean, it isn`t just any random company that she might have a personal vendetta against.

ALEMANY: No, it`s not. And this has been Elizabeth Warren`s pretty consistent position. It is really interesting as the campaign progresses to finally see positions, different positions between candidates in the Democratic Party differentiating from themselves. Cory Booker sort of, you know, appearing to take actually the sides of corporations a little bit more than Elizabeth Warren, which I think is a standpoint that you could have surmised from their positions in Congress.

But, you know, they both are part of a Congress that has failed really to regulate Facebook over the last few years, and I think both of them really need to grapple with their role in that. You know, France just finished their review in which the government conducted a six-month review internally in Facebook overseeing how their regulatory processes work and actually provided a report which Zuckerberg praised. And so, I don`t think these two things, breaking up Facebook and increasing regulation are necessarily mutually exclusive.

HUNT: Yes, Congressman, to that point about Congress -- I mean, do you think that the United States Congress is equipped to regulate these big tech companies, specifically Facebook? Are they capable of it?

KHANNA: We need to have more technology and knowledge. But we need to look to the Microsoft case. I think that was an example that worked, that government went after Microsoft. They said you couldn`t tie Internet Explorer to Windows. If you had done that, the Microsoft --

HUNT: We would all have to use Internet Explorer and our lives would be way harder and --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

KHANNA: Google would never have emerged, right? But it went to the D.C. Circuit, and the D.C. Circuit said you don`t have break them up. You need to make sure they can`t do bad mergers, they can`t be privileging their own platforms. So, there may be kind of ground.

I do think Elizabeth Warren has added a lot to the debate. I mean, she has called for stronger, thoughtful regulation. The question is, how do we get there? And I think the Microsoft case offers the paradigm.

HUNT: I`m going to put you a little bit on the spot here.

KHANNA: Sure.

HUNT: And I will admit that, you know, I`m not intimately familiar with where Bernie Sanders stands on this question. But you are co-chair of his campaign. Where does he fall on the spectrum of these 2020 candidates?

KHANNA: I haven`t asked him specifically. He usually focuses on Wall Street and defense contractors and airline industries. I mean, I don`t know his exact position on this. But I do know when he talks about technology, he often talks about how do we get universal broadband, how do we get technology into rural communities and jobs there. But you`d have to ask him or his campaign --

HUNT: Well, you are his campaign. That`s why I`m asking you.

KHANNA: I`m one of his co-chairs. I don`t want to -- I don`t want to misrepresent his nuanced view on this without talking to him about it.

HUNT: So, when it comes to the idea of breaking up Facebook, I mean, I think a lot of people, sort of, you know, Chris Hughes really turned heads because to explore your Microsoft analogy a little further, I mean, you`re talking about a centralization of power that is much different from a company that is selling computers and softwares to consumers, right? You`re instead talking about the fact that because all these people are using this platform, the platform itself has immense power.

How do you actually -- I mean, you must have to take steps that are slightly different than what happened in the Microsoft case to actually make it work.

KHANNA: Well, I think if you had scrutiny on mergers, right, I thought they shouldn`t have been allowed to acquire Instagram. I thought they shouldn`t have been allowed to acquire WhatsApp. And if you have different social media platforms, then you a choice.

I mean, I don`t think it`s the end of the world if someone doesn`t use Facebook. It would be the end of the world if someone didn`t have access to the Internet. That`s why Facebook is a utility. It`s not like water or electricity.

HUNT: Well, for a lot of small businesses, it does serve a purpose like a utility does.

KHANNA: Well, I think that there have to be regulations so that they shouldn`t be able to privilege their own products, they shouldn`t be able to bully vendors.

HUNT: They certainly bully the news industry in some cases as well.

KHANNA: And I think that should be looked at. But what we have to do is have a fact-based investigation and then have thoughtful regulation on privacy, on making sure that they`re not privileging their platform, on making sure they`re not getting a favorable deal against vendors.

But here is -- you say well, why not just break them up? There are two reasons. One, you don`t want China, Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu to become the social media platforms around the world. I mean, there is some competition there and --

HUNT: Do you think Facebook views itself as fundamentally American? Because sometimes when I talk to my sources who work there, they view themselves more as a global company than an American one. I mean, how important do you think that American identity is to Mark Zuckerberg?

KHANNA: I think they know they are an American company because they would never have succeeded under Chinese or European laws. I mean, it`s the American First Amendment and Section 230 that allowed a lot of these Internet companies to emerge. They aren`t censored. They have a much more competitive environment than Europe allows.

So, I think they understand that their success, they owed it to America, and they want to make sure some of those values continue.

Now, do they need to be more accountable? Absolutely. They need to do a better job to prevent interference from foreign actors. They need to do a better job to protect privacy. They need to do a better job to create jobs and not just in my district, but across the country.

They need to hire more people of color. It`s dismal what the hiring is of African Americans, African-American women.

So there are a lot of issues we can talk about. But we also should look at their success. The #MeToo movement wouldn`t have happened in the extent it did without Facebook. Black Lives Matter used Facebook. Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders, Donald Trump, they all use Facebook.

You know, Josh Hawley, the senator from Missouri, criticizing Titter saying we don`t need it. Well, why don`t you get off the platforms then? Of course the social media platforms have been critical to democracy. We need to make sure that they`re doing it in a positive way.

HUNT: Well, it seems like the question whether they have fundamentally, Juanita, undermined democracy by empowering authoritarians and misinformation.

TOLLIVER: I think that`s exactly right. With 2020 election coming up, all sorts of alarm bells are going off. Will our election be interfered in through this platform of Facebook, something that I think there has been a lot of evidence of? So how are user data being protected? How are consumers being protected, folks like you and me who use these platforms?

I think the other thing here is these candidates, while they`re on a spectrum, still belief in those same fundamental components, protect consumer data, ensure innovation in the industry and make sure that this platform is working for the American good.

HUNT: All right. Congressman Ro Khanna, thank you very much for coming on.

KHANNA: Thank you.

HUNT: It was always great, this particular conversation, it`s very interesting to have with you.

Extracts.SummaryText: ... Is It Just Me? Is it just me or is the news flow awful for stocks? Talk of limiting buybacks or taxing them. The move toward higher taxes in general (I favor a flat tax no deductions). Not news but the level of stock averages. Regulation talk here (new attorney general) and abroad of big tech. China and everything it stands for, forgetting trade. The rest of the world's conflicts that seem in every hemisphere. A weakening domestic economy (see Thursday morning's big miss on retail sales). ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VFH-3XK1-JCHV-V4WW-00000-00Kass: Stop the Nonsense That There Is No Inflation; 8 Bad Things for Stocks2019-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:06ZLexisNexisKass: Stop the Nonsense That There Is No Inflation; 8 Bad Things for StocksDoug Kass

The Fed shouldn't breathe easy just yet.



Can we please stop with this false narrative on inflation?
The January CPI saw no change at the headline level and a 0.2% core rate of increase, which brings the year-over-year increases to 1.6% and 2.2%, respectively. This was in line with expectations. Another decline in oil prices kept a lid on the headline figure. Food prices were up 0.2% month over month and 1.6% year over year.

In what continues to be the case, services inflation ex-energy remains persistent as it grew by 0.2% (month over month) and 2.8% (year over year).


Please stop telling us there is no inflation.

Rents and medical care continue to mostly drive this. Rent of Primary Residence was higher by 0.3% (month over month) and 3.4% (year over year). OER, the understated measure of housing inflation, was also up 0.3% and 3.2%, respectively. A 2.4% year-over-year increase in medical care services was partially offset by a decline in medical care commodities and drugs, both prescription and nonprescription. Overall, medical care costs rose 0.2% (month over month) and 1.9% (year over year).

Other important price increases for things that are important to the average family, tuition and childcare costs, rose 2.8%. College tuition and fees were higher by 2.9%, elementary and high school tuition was up by 4.4%. For those sports fans (my pals), ticket prices jumped by 7% year over year. For those that drive, insurance prices rose 3.4%. In direct response to tariffs, laundry equipment prices were up 7.2% year over year. On the other hand, if you fly a lot airline fares fell by 2.8% year over year.

Of note in January, we finally saw an increase in goods prices ex-food and fuel. They jumped by 0.4% month over month over month and actually brings the year-over-year gain to 0.3%. Higher prices for apparel was the main reason as they jumped by 1.1%. New and used car prices were up 0.2% and 0.1% month over month, respectively. Tariffs and high transportation costs are lending support to higher core goods prices.

Bottom line, the core rate of inflation is now up 0.2% a month for five straight months. The Fed shouldn't breathe easy just yet. If you watch the PCE instead, remember the biggest component, medical care, is mostly price fixed.

Inflation expectations in the TIPS market jumped 2 basis points immediately after the in line print. The 10-yr breakeven is at 1.86%, one basis point from a two-month high.


Is It Just Me?

Is it just me or is the news flow awful for stocks?



Talk of limiting buybacks or taxing them.
The move toward higher taxes in general (I favor a flat tax no deductions).
Not news but the level of stock averages.
Regulation talk here (new attorney general) and abroad of big tech.
China and everything it stands for, forgetting trade.
The rest of the world's conflicts that seem in every hemisphere.
A weakening domestic economy (see Thursday morning's big miss on retail sales).
The continuing loss of momentum in global economic growth.

I could go on but feel like the news is awful for business and corporate profits (and frankly the politics are awful for the world).
